overview_of_class: The course will use a case-method approach to explore and dissect the decisions editors make in pursuit of fundamental goals - e.g. truth/accuracy, fairness, timeliness, reflection of community, audience focus. One goal of the class is for students to begin developing their own sense of an editor's role in shaping journalistic product, their own set of standards, and a way of thinking about these issues. Cases will come from a range of media. They will include a blend of classic and current-news situations. Most will include practical, ethical, best practices and market-based considerations. Cases will be developed in consultation with practicing professionals, and often will include a how-we-decided element, revealed after robust class discussion. Weekly assignments will be a concise written recommendation and justification, to be graded for quality of thought and integration of principles, not for the recommendation itself. A final "exam" paper will be a written articulation of the student's evolved editing/publishing ethos, which takes account of industry standards, but allows for individual reasoning and goals.
